Syntax Highlighting

The YAML will control a lot of how a document looks
For example, if you wanted to render with a different syntax highlighter

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Table of Contents

Specify a table of contents in the YAML
A table of contents will be automatically generated for you based on your headers

# Header 1  ## Header 2

format: 
  html:
    toc: true
---

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
TOC - change depth

By default, the TOC will only go down to 3 levels
Change that with toc-depth:


---
format: 
  html:
    toc: true
    toc-depth: 5
---

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
TOC - location

For HTML format by default floats the table of contents to the right
The floating TOC can be used to navigate to sections of the document and also will automatically highlight the appropriate section as the user scrolls
The table of contents is responsive and will become hidden once the viewport becomes too narrow
You can alternatively position it at the left or in the body


---
format: 
  html:
    toc: true
    toc-location: left
---

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
TOC - title
You can customize the title used for the table of contents using the toc-title option

---
format: 
  html:
    toc: true
    toc-title: Contents
---

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:

Use custom text for the code display button (the default is just ‚ÄúCode‚Äù)

format:
  html:
    code-fold: true
    code-summary: "Show the code"
---

```{r}

a / b

[1] 3.142857

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Chunk Names

Use single word: chunk1
Or use hyphen (-) to separate words: chunk-1
Do not use spaces: chunk 1
Do not use underscore chunk_1
Chunk names can only be used once


Think kebabs, not snakes

bar-plot-1
bar-plot-2
hist-plot-1
model-1

ggplot(msleep, aes(sleep_rem, sleep_total)) + 
  geom_point())
```

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Inline R Code
Inline code is code that runs in your prose (i.e., not code chunks)
Two back ticks that enclose the letter ‚Äòr‚Äô produce inline code to be evaluated ` r code `
This is extremely useful in writing reports. Never have to update any numbers in text, regardless of changes to your models or data (if you are careful about it).


```{r}
a <- 22
b <- 7
```

script:
This is an example of inline code where I want to refer to the sum of a and b, which is `r a + b`
output:
This is an example of inline code where I want to refer to the sum of a and b, which is 29

text:
Inline Formatting

Italics

single asterisk *italicized text*
single underscore _ italicized text_

Bold

Inline code

execute code: back ticks + r `r code`
show code: back ticks no r `code`

tables

demo

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Editor Toolbar
The editor toolbar includes buttons for the most commonly used formatting commands:

Additional commands are available on the Format, Insert, and Table menus

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Learn more

Technical Writing covers features commonly used in scientific and technical writing, including citations, cross-references, footnotes, equations, embedded code, and LaTeX
Content Editing provides more depth on visual editor support for tables, lists, pandoc attributes, CSS styles, comments, symbols/emojis, etc
Shortcuts & Options documents the two types of shortcuts you can use with the editor: standard keyboard shortcuts and markdown shortcuts and describes various options for configuring the editor
Markdown Output describes how the visual editor parses and writes markdown and describes various ways you can customize this

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
References in .qmd

supports bibliographies in a wide variety of formats
we will use BibTeX

Add a bibliography to your document using the bibliography YAML metadata field

---
title: "My Document"
bibliography: references.bib
link-citations: true
---



Note the link-citations: true option which will make your citations hyperlinks to the corresponding bibliography entries

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
References
To include references in your .qmd, you must:

Create an external .bib file using LaTeX formatting

use RStudio to open new Text File

Include bibliography: name_of_your_bib_file.bib in your YAML

references.bib

Refer to the citations in text using @
For parenthesis around the citation, used brackets - [@BibTex_citekey]


What is BibTex?


What is a BibTex citekey?


Why are you doing this to us, Joe, we just want to code

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
BibTex

BibTex is just a text-based file format for lists of bibliography items like articles, books, R packages, etc.
BibTex is independent of any reference/citation style

(I happen to use APA, you may use something else)

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
BibTex and citekey
This is what BibTex looks like
The ‚Äúcitekey‚Äù is the key you will use to reference the entry in your prose

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Inserting citations
Insert citations in your prose

Insert -> Citation command, or
use markdown syntax directly

[@cite]
@cite


References are included automatically at the end of the document

Citations go inside square brackets and are separated by semicolons
Each citation must have a key, composed of @ plus the citekey from your .bib file

citekeys key must begin with a letter, digit, or _,
may contain alphanumerics, -, and internal punctuation characters (:.#$%&-+?<>~/)

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Citation options








Citation Style (using the tag)
Output




@Briggs11
Briggs and Weeks (2011)


[see @Baldwin2014; @Caruso2000]
(see Baldwin et al. 2014; Caruso 2000)


[@Linn02, p. 9]
(Linn and Haug 2002, p. 9)


[-@Goldhaber08]
(2008)

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Remember‚Ä¶
Cite R!

citation()

To cite R in publications use:

  R Core Team (2024). _R: A Language and Environment for Statistical
  Computing_. R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria.
  <https://www.R-project.org/>.

A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is

  @Manual{,
    title = {R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing},
    author = {{R Core Team}},
    organization = {R Foundation for Statistical Computing},
    address = {Vienna, Austria},
    year = {2024},
    url = {https://www.R-project.org/},
  }

We have invested a lot of time and effort in creating R, please cite it
when using it for data analysis. See also 'citation("pkgname")' for
citing R packages.



And the packages you used!

citation("tidyverse")

To cite package 'tidyverse' in publications use:

  Wickham H, Averick M, Bryan J, Chang W, McGowan LD, Fran√ßois R,
  Grolemund G, Hayes A, Henry L, Hester J, Kuhn M, Pedersen TL, Miller
  E, Bache SM, M√ºller K, Ooms J, Robinson D, Seidel DP, Spinu V,
  Takahashi K, Vaughan D, Wilke C, Woo K, Yutani H (2019). "Welcome to
  the tidyverse." _Journal of Open Source Software_, *4*(43), 1686.
  doi:10.21105/joss.01686 <https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686>.

A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is

  @Article{,
    title = {Welcome to the {tidyverse}},
    author = {Hadley Wickham and Mara Averick and Jennifer Bryan and Winston Chang and Lucy D'Agostino McGowan and Romain Fran√ßois and Garrett Grolemund and Alex Hayes and Lionel Henry and Jim Hester and Max Kuhn and Thomas Lin Pedersen and Evan Miller and Stephan Milton Bache and Kirill M√ºller and Jeroen Ooms and David Robinson and Dana Paige Seidel and Vitalie Spinu and Kohske Takahashi and Davis Vaughan and Claus Wilke and Kara Woo and Hiroaki Yutani},
    year = {2019},
    journal = {Journal of Open Source Software},
    volume = {4},
    number = {43},
    pages = {1686},
    doi = {10.21105/joss.01686},
  }

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Citations in .qmd demo

Open a new qmd document
In your YAML, add a new line for bibliography: followed by the name of your bibliography file, which should be in the same directory, and should be the bare name (i.e., not quotes)

bibliography: references.bib

Open a text file in RStudio, save it with a .bib extension

name it references.bib

Go to Google Scholar and find a reference to cite. Copy and paste the citation into your .bib file using Google‚Äôs cite option
Include a reference to the citation in your qmd file
Reference Section: references are included automatically at the end of the document (note: default is not APA format)

html - if you are rendering to html, you will automatically get a ‚ÄúReferences‚Äù heading
pdf - if you are rendering to PDF

include a page break in your prose so your References are on a separate page: \newpage
include # References as the last line of your document to give it a heading title


Render

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Citations in .Rmd demo

Open a new qmd document
In your YAML, add a new line for bibliography: followed by the name of your bibliography file, which should be in the same directory, and should be the bare name (i.e., not quotes)


bibliography: references.bib


---
title: "Bibliography example"
author: "Joe Nese"
format: pdf
bibliography: references.bib
---


Open a text file in RStudio, save it as references.bib

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Citations in .Rmd demo

Find references to cite

You can copy/paste the citation into your .bib file using Google‚Äôs  ‚ÄúCite‚Äù option
You can (and should!) cite the R packages you use! citation("package-name") and citation() to cite R

Include a reference to the citation in your .qmd file
Let‚Äôs render to PDF

Include a page break so your citations are on a separate page (\newpage)
Add the # References heading as the last line of your document to give the section a title

Render as PDF

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Tables
Many options

knitr::kable() for basic tables of any sort

try booktabs = TRUE argument for APA-like table format
Use {kableExtra} for extensions (example for html and pdf)

{gt}

tidy- and APA-friendly (with effort)

{DT}

great for displaying a lot of data in a manageable way
multiple pages, search and sort features, etc.

{reactable}

great for displaying a lot of data in a manageable way
multiple pages, search and sort features, etc.

{gtsummary}

amazing for summary tables

title: Week 6: Quarto
text:
Table chunk options
For many tables, you may have to specify #| results: asis or you can end up with wacky display
